awd_titl_txt: Variability in oxygen concentrations in Atlantic intermediate waters during the last deglaciation
awd_abstract_narration:
Oxygen is a primary component of the biological and chemical cycles of the ocean. Its involvement in photosynthesis and respiration links the changes of oxygen concentration to that of carbon in the ocean, and ultimately in the atmosphere. As the oceans take up more and more carbon, oxygen concentrations in the ocean are declining, with the potential to reach levels low enough to reduce biodiversity. The last ice age provides a natural experiment to investigate how oxygen concentrations may have varied under different climate conditions in order to help forecast what might happen in the future. Most previous studies have only been able to distinguish the relative change in oxygen concentrations (higher or lower), but in this project a new application will be developed that can quantitatively constrain oxygen concentrations in the past. In regions like the tropical Atlantic, where oxygen minimum zones (OMZs) approach but do not reach a total absence of oxygen today, it is critical to pinpoint the environmental conditions that can cross that threshold into an absence of oxygen. This project will promote training and learning for several participants, including one early-career scientist without previous NSF support and one undergraduate summer student.


This project will produce high quality U-Th isotope and trace element data in a suite of intermediate depth sediment cores from the western tropical Atlantic and one site under the eastern tropical OMZ. These data will be used to test hypotheses regarding the evolution of bottom water oxygen concentrations (BW [O2]) during the last deglaciation in response to changes in the intensity of the eastern tropical OMZ. Specifically this project seeks to understand how the spatial extent and absolute magnitude of the OMZ has varied , and how these changes may relate to intermediate water ventilation and carbon storage. The first component of this proposal involves method development of a quantitative proxy system for BW [O2]. It parameterizes sedimentary [O2] with authigenic uranium and organic carbon fluxes with Baxs fluxes to generate a comprehensive approach to reconstructing BW [O2]. This component focuses on the Demerara Rise, where preliminary data indicate a high probability for successful application, and then it combines the new data from the Demerara Rise with additional work in the Arabian Sea and previously published data from the Pacific to prospect the global utility of the approach. The second component of this proposal investigates how and why oxygen concentrations in tropical intermediate waters may have varied in the past in response to changes in zonal circulation, meridional circulation, and organic matter fluxes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Oxygen concentrations are a primary chemical characteristic of the ocean, responsible not only for life in the deep but also for driving the biogeochemical cycles of C, Mn, Fe, and many other trace elements. Changes in oxygen concentrations in the ocean can have a major impact on the cycling of important macronutrients like nitrogen and phosphorous, as well as trace metals like Mn and Fe. As the oceans take up anthropogenic carbon, oxygen concentrations are declining, but how fast and how intense the deoxygenation will be is poorly constrained. In order to understand the mechanisms and feedbacks that drive oxygen variability in the ocean, we can look into the past at the times when oxygen concentrations were lower.

In this project, we focused on the Last Glacial Maximum, when the ocean sequestered most of 100 ppm of CO2 lost from the atmosphere. Because oxygen and carbon are linked by respiration, storing so much carbon in the deep sea must have consumed oxygen, leading to much lower oxygen concentrations in the Last Glacial Maximum relative to today. While this relationship has long been known qualitatively, the actual amount of oxygen lost from the ocean has been difficult to quantify. Our objectives were to 1) develop new tools for quantifying oxygen concentrations in the past and 2) use those new tools to investigate oxygen change in the Last Glacial Maximum and subsequent deglaciation.

One novel tool is the porosity of benthic foraminifera shells. When oxygen concentrations are low, benthic foraminifera need more pores to facilitate gas uptake and exchange. Our new data combined with previously published measurements demonstrated that this tool is effective at reconstructing oxygen concentrations between 0-100 mmol/kg. Another tool was the uranium to barium ratio (U/Ba) of bulk sediments. Uranium has been used to qualitatively reconstruct oxygen concentrations in the past, but the novelty of this tool is that it can account for changes in organic carbon fluxes by dividing by barium concentrations. Although U/Ba can only be used with a region-specific calibration, it is sensitive over 100-250 mmol/kg, a range for which only one other oxygen proxy can capture variability.

Applying these tools, we found that oxygen concentrations in the intense Arabian Sea Oxygen Minimum Zone (OMZ) were similar between the last ice age and the pre-industrial time period, which suggests that oxygen concentrations in this region may not be as sensitive to climate change as previously thought. In the tropical Atlantic, in contrast, oxygen concentrations were drastically lower (by ~100 mmol/kg) in intermediate water depths (1500-2500 m) during the Last Glacial Maximum due to changes in ocean circulation and interactions between the atmosphere and the surface ocean where the water masses formed. The observed amplitude of change is much larger than predicted by models, and this suggests that the mid-to-deep Atlantic may be more sensitive to climate change than previously thought.

This project included training and professional development for one early-career scientist without previous NSF support and two post-docs working on independent projects, both of whom have gone on to tenure-track positions. All data generated by this award are archived at the National Centers for Environmental Information and the Index to Geological Samples at NGDC. This grant funded a total of 4 peer-reviewed publications and 4 conference abstracts.
